thread.title: Investors jostle for slice of Atlassian IPO
thread.title_full: Investors jostle for slice of Atlassian IPO | afr.com

author: afr.com
title: Investors jostle for slice of Atlassian IPO
text:
Atlassian founders Mike Cannon-Brookes and Scott Farquhar. by Rose Powell Ruth Liew Before it has even been officially announced, Atlassian's upcoming public listing has global and local investors positioning for a slice of the company.
The software giant is worth more than $3 billion and has reportedly filed the initial paperwork to list in the United States in what is set to become the biggest IPO by an Australian technology company.
Fund managers spoken to by Fairfax Media said the US IPO was both an attractive proposition, and a loss for Australian stock market, which has failed to attract a hugely significant listing.
Speaking to Fairfax Media prior to the weekend's stories about Atlassian's IPO plans, partner at Silicon Valley heavyweight Accel Partners, Rich Wong, said founders Mike Cannon-Brookes and Scott Farquhar were exactly the kind of leaders investors sought out.
Accel Partners and Atlassian board member Rich Wong. Tony Avelar Founders admired Accel Partners has become well-known in tech circles for backing early stage and fast growing companies. It was an early backer of Facebook and is also an investor in New Zealand success story Xero. It invested $US60 million into Atlassian in 2010.
"Mike and Scott are not just big thinkers, they back it up and deliver quarter after quarter, year after year," Mr Wong said.
"They were and are very proud of their Australian heritage and roots. I think they are evidence of Australian tech companies being able to go global as opposed to just being a national or regional company."
Perpetual Investments global equities portfolio manager Garry Laurence said his company would look to invest in Atlassian. Peter Rae News of Atlassian's listing in the US comes amid a burgeoning appetite among Australian investors to pour money offshore.
Figures from Investment Trends showed 29 per cent of investors intend to pump money into the equities market as they worry about a slowdown in China, and that 12 per cent will invest in international assets such as global shares.
Loss for ASX Hamilton Wealth Management chief executive Will Hamilton said they would be reviewing the Atlassian float to possibly buy-in and described the decision to list in the US as "bad news for the ASX".
Hamilton Wealth Management chief executive Will Hamilton said they would be reviewing the Atlassian float to possibly buy-in and described the the decision to list in the US was "bad news for the ASX". Wayne Taylor "The demand for offshore exposure is increasing and as for companies like Atlassian listing offshore, that's where the majority of the earnings are coming from and they can raise the capital more effectively," Mr Hamilton said.
Perpetual Investments global equities portfolio manager Garry Laurence said the decision by the company's executive to list in the US was disappointing but not surprising.
"It is a bit of a shame for the Australian market, but our best quality companies are listing offshore. It does reflect the dynamics of the Australian market, and they must feel that tech IPOs are better suited for the US markets. There's clearly more capital available offshore than in Australia."
Mr Laurence said they would be looking to invest in Atlassian, depending on the valuation and growth strategies, which are yet to be disclosed.
"We think it's a high quality business. It's just that getting more information around the dynamics of growth going forward," Mr Laurence said.
Tech staying at home Technology companies are increasingly seeking out the ASX to list their companies. In the last year, the number of tech IPOs more than doubled, from 12 in 2014 to 30 in the 2015 financial year.
The ASX's head of new listings Max Cunningham said it has been fielding interest as well as pursuing companies in Australia, New Zealand, Singapore and Silicon Valley.
"Over the last few years we've seen a great number of investors turning their minds from the long established practice of backing startups in the mining sector to applying the same discernment to reviewing high growth tech companies," Mr Cunningham said.
As for Atlassian, Mr Cunningham said companies would always seek out the right markets for them.
"They've got some very good advisors, very interesting shareholders and some great management so from our perspective we just wish them all the best," Mr Cunningham said.
The largest technology business float on Australian markets to date was MYOB Group, which listed in March with a market cap of $1.9 billion.
